answers.answer: Doesn't sound like diabetes to me.  Looking forward to lab results though.  Please post them.  Yes they will be different I think and I think substantially.  Important thing to note is what standard they use in their results.  Many different labs will issue different results on the same blood sample because they use a different standard.  Important thing is how you fit into their standard.For the Neuropathy.  You might have gotten it during your gestational diabetes and it has taken a long time to develop into something more.Good luck on lab results :)

thank you so much for your post to me, I appreciate the time you took to do that.  It's so strange.  The GD I had was actually brought on by a severe case of PUPPPS (Priuritic Uticarial Papules and Plaques of Pregnancy) and because of that...I had to be put on high doses of Prednisone (worse case they had ever seen).  I only had it weeks 32-38 - I can't imagine I could have developed neuropathy from that amount of time, cause as soon as I gave birth, the PUPPPS went completely away with help from the steroids.I guess it's something to consider though.  It doesn't explain the complete loss of reflexes in my ankles though does it?I need to stop questioning why I have it and just live with the face that I have it.Thanks.
I forgot one sentence - the high doses of prednisone is what shot my blood sugar through the roof - was up in the 250-300 range a lot of the time.  That's why they called it Gest Diab.

I have been on Lyrica for a bit now, even though was only just diagnosed with diabetes.  I started Lyrica when it was approved for fibromyalgia.  In addition to my joint/muscle pain, the Lyrica has helped my raynauds syndrome (lack of blood flow down to the hands and feet which makes them cold all the time).  I am told that it was orginally designed for diabetic nerve damage or nerve damage from other causes.  Anyways, ask your doctor about Lyrica and see if it helps.  DOwnside of Lyrica, is I gained weight and the copay is high because there is no generic.
My Diabetes came on in 3 days and I got Neuropathy from that really bad.  Not sure if GD can do the same but time does not seem to be an issue with Neuropathy.

question: I have neuropathy in both of my feet they are always burning.  Neuro and I are trying to figure out why I have neuropathy.  MS and most everything else has been ruled out.  Was wondering how different my monitor numbers would be to the lab numbers.  (i.e. I do have a BS monitor because I had Gestational and I also had Insulin Resistance a few years ago).  Are they drastically different usually?  I have been fine for a few years now, but recently started taking Neurotonin and have noticed my numbers are higher (170-199 range) 1-2 hours after I eat, but do always come back down to normal, so that's a good sign.I thought it would be neat to see what my BS's were on my monitor at the same intervals they took blood from my arm.  Based on my results and the normal values for this test, I'll probably get a call saying I don't have diabetes, which is great news.....but on the other hand leaves a question to why I have neuropathy in my feet.  Anyway, I will post when I hear my actual test results, but these are the ones I got on my monitor.75 mg glucose given.Fasting - 112 (it was 132 when I got up - then 112 by the time I got to the hospital).1/2 hr reading was 2501 hr reading was 2021.5 hrs. was 1332 hrs. was 87I don' t know unless there are some other guidelines out there, I probably don't have diabetes, which I would be SO RELIEVED if I didn't.  If that's the case, I will just take my neurotonin for my foot neuropathy and be done with it.  Never find that cause, what's the point.  I think it's helping my burning feet now, so that's a huge relief.  But there's that "burning" question in the back of my mind - why on earth did I get neuropathy to begin with?I'll post when I get ACTUAL results
title: Have neuropathy in feet - GTT this AM - Question (m)..
